abstract.p: Yes Yoko Ono is title of exhibition that opens on Oct 18 at Japan House Gallery; show is billed as first American retrospective devoted to Ono's avant-garde art; photo; Grolier Club in Manhattan is holding retrospective exhibition of work of German-born illustrator Fritz Kredel, to mark centenary of his birth; exhibition Made in California: Art, Image and Identity, 1900-2000, to run at Los Angeles County Museum of Art through Feb 25; photo; Pete Hamill to read from works of Damon Runyon, at Gotham Readers series under auspices of Museum of City of New York (M)

block.p: Seen Anew ''Yes Yoko Ono'' is the title of the exhibition that opens today at the Japan House Gallery, at 333 East 47th Street, Manhattan. Billed as the first American retrospective devoted to Ms. Ono's avant-garde art, the show spans 40 years and features about 150 works. ''Yes'' examines her role in the avant-garde movement Fluxus; her contributions to Conceptual Art in New York, London and Tokyo; her concerts, experimental films, vocal recordings and public art, including works with John Lennon; and her more recent interactive installations and site-specific art. Also represented is her collaborative work with avant-garde figures like John Cage, George Maciunas, Nam June Paik, Charlotte Moorman, Andy Warhol and Ornette Coleman. The show runs through Jan. 14 before a tour destined for Minneapolis; Houston; Cambridge, Mass.; and San Francisco, among other places.

Tribute He illustrated Eleanor Roosevelt's book ''Christmas.'' He created a woodcut of the presidential seal for the inauguration of John F. Kennedy. His virtuosic pen-and-ink drawings, watercolors and woodcuts illustrated fairy tales, children's books, religious works, cookbooks, fiction and nonfiction for private presses and trade book publishers. His name was Fritz Kredel. To mark the centenary of this prize-winning German-born illustrator, who came to the United States in 1938 and died in 1973, the Grolier Club, at 47 East 60th Street, Manhattan, is holding a retrospective exhibition. On view through Nov. 18, the ''Fritz Kredel Centennial Exhibition'' includes works never before shown.

State of Mind In the 150th year of statehood for California, a major exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art will address the relationship between the state's arts and image in the last century. Running from Sunday through Feb. 25, ''Made in California: Art, Image, and Identity, 1900-2000'' features more than 800 works. The mediums include painting, sculpture, photography, graphic art, decorative art, costume and video. In addition more than 400 cultural documents -- tourist brochures, rock posters, labor pamphlets and documentary photographs from public and private collections nationwide -- will be assembled to convey California's history and image.

Guys, Dolls et al. How's this for a winning New York pairing: Pete Hamill and Damon Runyon? They'll be found together at 6 tonight at Chumley's, at 86 Bedford Street, Greenwich Village. With readings from his favorite Runyon passages, Mr. Hamill will usher in ''Gangs, Gangsters and Gangstas,'' a new season of the peripatetic Gotham Readers series under the auspices of the Museum of the City of New York.
